question: Reflecting on your time at PayPal, how did your early exposure to public bug bounty programs shape your view on utilizing crowdsourced security?

inputs.question: Reflecting on your time at PayPal, how did your early exposure to public bug bounty programs shape your view on utilizing crowdsourced security?

conversationHistory.content: Can you please share your background and your role at your current organization?

"My current role is a Senior Manager of Product Management. My background is in engineering and product management with a focus on security. I spent several years working in security-related roles at Magento, an e-commerce company acquired by PayPal, eBay, and later by Adobe. At those companies, I worked directly on crowdsourced security. PayPal was one of the very first companies to have a public bug bounty program."

You mentioned PayPal's early adoption of public bug bounty programs; could you elaborate on how that experience has influenced your current approach to integrating crowdsourced security into product management?

questions: Can you describe how your early experience with PayPal's public bug bounty program may have influenced your current approach to crowdsourced security in product management?
In what ways has your exposure to PayPal's pioneering bug bounty initiatives shaped your understanding or implementation of crowdsourced security strategies?
How did your time at PayPal, particularly with the early public bug bounty initiative, contribute to the development of your current views on integrating crowdsourced security?
